Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(2) Summary

APIs are the only visible parts of services in API-based service landscapes. The technical aspect of APIs has been widely discussed with description languages such as Swagger/OpenAPI. The non-functional aspects are harder to formalize, but can also benefit from a framework in which information can be represented and used. The idea of "API Labels" is equivalent to that of standardized labeling systems in other product spaces, for example for food or for machinery. There often is a framework in place that allows users to understand a few key (and often safety-critical) aspects of the product. This framework is not intended to be a complete and exhaustive description of the product. Instead, it focuses on areas that are important and helpful to make an initial product selection. In the API space, numerous standards and best practices have evolved how APIs can be described and/or documented. However, there still is some uncertainty how to best combine these, and how to use them so that API description, documentation, and labeling can be combined. This presentation provides an overview of the existing approaches, how to use them, and proposes an additional layer on top of which API labeling becomes more unified, and thus more useful.

(10) Label Properties and Problems



Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(11) Labels are Languages

  • Diverse and dynamic set of products
  • Decentralized production and consumption
  • Market regulation for consumer safety and information
  • Never forget about Goodhart's Law [https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Goodhart%27s_law]
    • When a measure becomes a target, it ceases to be a good measure.


Motivation Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(12) Labels are Constraints

  • Labels emerge for market observability or management
    • Producers may use them for product differentiation
    • Consumers may use them for product selection
    • Market regulators balance freedom, safety, and transparency
  • Labels provide a framework how to enter and succeed in a market
    • Production is only visible when required for label verification/certification
  • Labels tend to emerge when markets become big and opaque
    • Establishing visibility/transparency/accountability/safety/trust

(14) Digital Transformation is Digital Deconstruction



API Product Landscapes Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(15) Transformation 1-2-3

  1. Vision (Why) explains the ultimate goal
    • Be more active when it comes to exploring new opportunities
    • Be more reactive when it comes to adapting to new challenges
  2. Strategy (What) maps out resource allocation
    • Business strategy focuses on success in faster-changing environments
    • Organization strategy focuses on making the organization being more change-ready
    • Technical strategy focuses on how to enable and support constant transformation
  3. Execution (How) details what to do along the way
    • Loose coupling for minimizing IT-inflicted dependencies → Microservices
    • Agility for embracing feedback as necessary development input → DevOps
    • Landscapes as a way to move from integration to interaction → APIs


API Product Landscapes Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

API Product Landscapes Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(17) Internal and External API Usage



API Product Landscapes Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(18) API Usage Scenarios

  1. Private APIs for internal usage
    • Trust is a smaller issue (no intentionally malicious usage)
    • Risk needs to be managed for operational stability
  2. Partner/Public APIs provided to external consumers
    • Trust can be used as differentiating factor
    • Risk management means keeping SLAs and other claims
  3. Partner/Public APIs consumed from external providers
    • Trust depends on the relationship with the provider
    • Risk should be managed as external dependency

(20) Continuous Architecting: Continuity and Scale



Continuous Architecting Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(21) Observability

  • Continuous Architecting is based on four main principles
    1. Design Products with feedback and changeability in mind
    2. Evolve Products based on feedback and with minimal breakage
    3. Landscape Design supports product continuity and landscape evolvability
    4. Landscape Evolution is based on product and consumer feedback
  • Observability is a key principle complementing APIs and Microservices
    • Implementation details are hidden and APIs are the only interface
    • API your APIs: Anything that is interesting should become an API
  • Observability is based on and complements Continuous Architecting
    • When new observability needs arise they can be added to the landscape and/or products
    • Observability makes sure that the landscape can be observed and improved


Continuous Architecting Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(24) OpenAPI

  • OpenAPI Info Object [https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/3.0.2.md#info-object] represents API metadata as part of an API description
    • Small set of predefined fields (title and version are required)
    • Extensions can be added via OpenAPI Specification Extensions [https://github.com/OAI/OpenAPI-Specification/blob/master/versions/3.0.2.md#specificationExtensions]
info:
  title: Sample Pet Store App
  description: This is a sample server for a pet store.
  termsOfService: http://example.com/terms/
  contact:
    name: API Support
    url: http://www.example.com/support
    email: support@example.com
  license:
    name: Apache 2.0
    url: https://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0.html
  version: 1.0.1
  • Open-API-info-object.yaml


Existing Labeling Schemes Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(25) APIs.json 

{
    "name": "Fitbit",
    "description": "Fitbit designs products that track everyday health and fitness, empowering and inspiring people to lead healthier, more active lives.",
    "image": "https://www.fitbit.com/images/common/logo_with_trademark.png",
    "tags": [
        "fitness"
    ],
    "created": "2015-01-01",
    "modified": "2015-01-01",
    "url": "https://www.fitbit.com/apis.json",
    "specificationVersion": "0.14",
    "apis": [
        {
            "name": "Fitbit Web API",
            "description": "Fitbit designs products that track everyday health and fitness, empowering and inspiring people to lead healthier, more active lives.",
            "image": "https://www.fitbit.com/images/common/logo_with_trademark.png",
            "humanURL": "https://dev.fitbit.com/",
            "baseURL": "https://api.fitbit.com/",
  • apis.json (line 1-18)


Existing Labeling Schemes Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(26) Pivio

  • Pivio [http://pivio.io/] is a tool and a data format [http://pivio.io/docs/#section-dataformat]
    • A small number of mandatory fields (id/name/short_name/type/owner/description)
    • A small number of optional fields
    • Extensions can be added via custom extensions [http://pivio.io/docs/#_custom_extensions]
id: next-generation-print-2342-2413-9189-1990
name: Next Generation Print Service
short_name: NGPS
type: service
owner: Team Goldfinger
description: Prints all kinds of things. Now with 3D printing support.
vcsroot: git://git.vcs.local/UBP
contact: Auric Goldfinger
lifecycle: production
tags:
 - Old
 - Demo
links:
  homepage: http://wiki.local/ubp
  buildchain: http://ci.local/ubp
  api_docs: http://docs.local/ubp-api
  • pivio.yaml

(31) OCD? Landscape Management!



Labels in Real Life Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(32) Why Do Labels Work?

Goal: Information about all/many products in large and diverse landscapes.

Non-goal: Every possible detail about every single product.

  • Simple/simplified description of important product aspects
  • Supported across large and diverse sets of products (possibly across categories)
  • Defined/assigned/verified/certified by various players (owners/managers/authority/automated)

(38) API Label Format



API Label Strawman Erik Wilde (@dret): May Contain Nuts: The Case for API Labeling

(39) API Label Types

  • Requirements for API label types
    • Well-known and continuously evolving set of existing label types
    • Easy discovery of current set of well-known label types
    • Robust coexistence of well-known and proprietary label types
